fields.description:

Started an windows instance.

Later I increased the cache size, restarted eucalyptus-nc service and able to run an windows instance on the same Node Controller it failed previously.

Observation:
The NC started with smaller root size, thus NC allocates the smaller work size limit. But when we increase the filesystem size, it doesn't increase the NC work size. But during lunch instance request somehow it is getting all the bits needed and sends running signal while it has got nothing in cache directory.
fields.summary: NC provides false booting report for windows instance due to insufficient cache size

comments.body:
It appears we use grub to boot windows instances? Or is there any other explanation on how grub landed there in the 1st place while booting a windows instance?

Any insight or detailed explanation on the booting process for windows instances from start to beginning would help.

Shaon, 

If this issue is still a problem, can you provide us more information in the form of a SUP ticket so that we can ensure we action off this EUCA ticket accordingly.

There is no SUP ticket for this one, this is what we've found during test and also we've seen another user facing this same issue on #eucalyptus (freenode).

Thanks,
Shaon

This loks easily reproducible.  To reiterate, the issue here is that the instance went to the "running" when it failed to boot specifically due to lack of disk space on the NC.  This should not happen.

To put it differently, it appears that when a full-disk image gets downloaded directly to work space (rather than to cache space, from where it is cloned to work space), there is something wrong with the image.

Well, I see the difference now, correct me if I am wrong,

Failed:
{code}
[Thu Sep 13 06:39:58 2012][002269][EUCADEBUG ] {3203385088} walrus_request: writing GET/GetDecryptedImage output
[Thu Sep 13 06:39:58 2012][002269][EUCADEBUG ] {3203385088}                 from http://10.104.1.163:8773/services/Walrus/windows_bkt/windowsserver2008r2_datacenter_x64.kvm.img.manifest.xml

{code}

{code}
[Thu Sep 13 02:32:26 2012][022596][EUCADEBUG ] {162748160} walrus_request: writing GET/GetDecryptedImage output
[Thu Sep 13 02:32:26 2012][022596][EUCADEBUG ] {162748160}                 from http://10.104.1.163:8773/services/Walrus/windows_bkt/windowsserver2008r2_datacenter_x64.kvm.img.manifest.xml
[Thu Sep 13 02:32:26 2012][022596][EUCADEBUG ] {162748160}                 to /var/lib/eucalyptus/instances/cache/emi-00393AEE-ca325a02/blocks
{code}

So, when cache size is not enough, it downloads to the work directory if it finds available space there. Is it like, it had created the paths to the cache directory and finally downloaded the decrypted file in to the work directory instead of failing to download it to the cache directory.

Let me know, if there are some other variables I am missing.

Thanks for having a look at it.

regards,
shaon
We'll set the NC_CACHE_SIZE to 0 and determine if this is a bug and then assign to Dima if so.

[~mdshaonimran] - thanks for the link to the image. Yes, you got it right: when there is no cache space, the image is downloaded into work space. Based on the logs, all the steps succeed, but clearly you somehow end up with an invalid disk image. So we'll try to reproduce this to understand what the logs are not telling us.

{code}

It seems that the issue can be reproduced.

This is, indeed, a bug. Because Windows image requires no preparation, when it bypasses the cache, one ends up with just a .blocks file in work space, with no loop devices or device mapper entries involved. However, when instance.xml is generated, the assumption is that the blob is available on a loopback device, so a no-longer used device name ends up in instance.xml, so libvirt.xml ends up pointing both disks to a loopback device that may point somewhere or nowhere at all.
